Perceptron math part 2

November 14, 2025

The Update Rule (Derived, Not Memorised)

Given a misclassified sample xi,yix_i, y_ixi​,yi​, the perceptron update is:

w←w+ηyixi,b←b+ηyiw \leftarrow w + \eta y_i x_i,\quad b \leftarrow b + \eta y_iw←w+ηyi​xi​,b←b+ηyi​

How do we know a point is on the wrong side?

We check if the prediction matches the true label:

  • Compute the score: w⋅xi+bw \cdot x_i + bw⋅xi​+b
  • Get the prediction: y^i=sign(w⋅xi+b)\hat{y}_i = \text{sign}(w \cdot x_i + b)y^​i​=sign(w⋅xi​+b) (either +1 or -1)
  • Compare with true label yiy_iyi​ (also +1 or -1)

If y^i≠yi\hat{y}_i \neq y_iy^​i​=yi​, the point is misclassified. Equivalently, we can check if yi(w⋅xi+b)≤0y_i(w \cdot x_i + b) \le 0yi​(w⋅xi​+b)≤0:

  • When correctly classified: yiy_iyi​ and (w⋅xi+b)(w \cdot x_i + b)(w⋅xi​+b) have the same sign, so their product is positive
  • When misclassified: they have opposite signs, so yi(w⋅xi+b)≤0y_i(w \cdot x_i + b) \le 0yi​(w⋅xi​+b)≤0

Simple intuition:

  • If a point is on the wrong side, we “pull” the hyperplane toward it by moving the weights in the direction of the point (if it should be positive) or away from it (if it should be negative).
  • The learning rate η\etaη controls how big each step is—too large and you overshoot, too small and learning is slow.
  • Think of it like adjusting a line on a graph: if a blue point ends up in the red region, you tilt the line to move it to the correct side.

Why this works (the detailed math):

First, a crucial clarification:

  • We don’t have a weight for each point. We have one shared weight vector www that applies to all points.
  • If your data has ddd features (e.g., height, weight, age), then www has ddd components: w=(w1,w2,...,wd)w = (w_1, w_2, ..., w_d)w=(w1​,w2​,...,wd​)
  • Every point uses the same www to compute its score: score=w⋅x+b\text{score} = w \cdot x + bscore=w⋅x+b
  • When we update www based on a misclassified point, we’re adjusting the shared model, which affects how all points are classified going forward

The intuitive picture: Think of the weight vector www as defining the “direction” of your decision boundary. When a point is misclassified:

  • If a point should be class +1 but is on the -1 side, we adjust www to point more toward that point’s location
  • If a point should be class -1 but is on the +1 side, we adjust www to point more away from that point’s location
  • Each update is a small nudge that makes the boundary better for that specific point, while (hopefully) not breaking correct classifications

Now the detailed math:

When a point xix_ixi​ is misclassified with true label yiy_iyi​, we know yi(w⋅xi+b)≤0y_i(w \cdot x_i + b) \le 0yi​(w⋅xi​+b)≤0. The update rule does two things:

  1. Nudging the hyperplane in the right direction:

    • The update adds ηyixi\eta y_i x_iηyi​xi​ to the weight vector: w←w+ηyixiw \leftarrow w + \eta y_i x_iw←w+ηyi​xi​
    • Concrete example: If xi=(3,2)x_i = (3, 2)xi​=(3,2) should be class +1 but was misclassified:
      • We add η⋅(+1)⋅(3,2)=(η⋅3,η⋅2)\eta \cdot (+1) \cdot (3, 2) = (\eta \cdot 3, \eta \cdot 2)η⋅(+1)⋅(3,2)=(η⋅3,η⋅2) to www
      • This makes www point more in the direction of (3,2)(3, 2)(3,2), which helps classify this point correctly
    • After the update, the new score for xix_ixi​ becomes: (w+ηyixi)⋅xi+(b+ηyi)(w + \eta y_i x_i) \cdot x_i + (b + \eta y_i)(w+ηyi​xi​)⋅xi​+(b+ηyi​)
    • Expanding: w⋅xi+b+ηyi(xi⋅xi+1)w \cdot x_i + b + \eta y_i (x_i \cdot x_i + 1)w⋅xi​+b+ηyi​(xi​⋅xi​+1)
    • Since xi⋅xi=∥xi∥2≥0x_i \cdot x_i = \|x_i\|^2 \ge 0xi​⋅xi​=∥xi​∥2≥0, we’re adding a positive term (when η>0\eta > 0η>0)
    • This increases the score in the direction of yiy_iyi​, moving the point toward (or across) the hyperplane
    • Key insight: The update uses the point’s own coordinates (xix_ixi​) to adjust www—points with larger feature values have more influence on the corresponding weights

  2. Increasing alignment with the true separator:

    • If a perfect separator w∗w^*w∗ exists (one that correctly classifies all points), we want our www to point in a similar direction
    • The dot product w⋅w∗w \cdot w^*w⋅w∗ measures how aligned our weights are with the perfect solution (larger = more aligned)
    • After an update: (w+ηyixi)⋅w∗=w⋅w∗+ηyi(xi⋅w∗)(w + \eta y_i x_i) \cdot w^* = w \cdot w^* + \eta y_i (x_i \cdot w^*)(w+ηyi​xi​)⋅w∗=w⋅w∗+ηyi​(xi​⋅w∗)
    • For correctly separable data, yi(xi⋅w∗)≥0y_i (x_i \cdot w^*) \ge 0yi​(xi​⋅w∗)≥0 (points are on the correct side of w∗w^*w∗)
    • So each update adds a non-negative term, meaning w⋅w∗w \cdot w^*w⋅w∗ increases—our weights become more aligned with the true separator
    • Intuition: Each correction moves us closer to the “ideal” weight vector that would perfectly separate the data

  3. Margin improvement:

    • The margin is the minimum distance from any point to the hyperplane
    • As www aligns better with w∗w^*w∗, correctly classified points move further from the hyperplane
    • This increases the “safety zone” around the decision boundary

  4. Bounded weight growth:

    • While w⋅w∗w \cdot w^*w⋅w∗ increases, the norm ∥w∥\|w\|∥w∥ grows at a controlled rate
    • This bounded growth is crucial for the convergence proof—it ensures we don’t need infinite updates

The key insight: Each update makes a small correction that:

  • Moves misclassified points toward the correct side
  • Increases alignment with the optimal solution (if one exists)
  • Does so in a controlled way that guarantees convergence for separable data

⸻

Convergence Theorem (The Cleanest Part)

If the data is separable with margin γ\gammaγ—meaning:

yi(w∗⋅xi+b∗)≥γy_i(w^* \cdot x_i + b^*) \ge \gammayi​(w∗⋅xi​+b∗)≥γ

—then the perceptron converges in at most:

O(R2γ2)O\left(\frac{R^2}{\gamma^2}\right)O(γ2R2​)

updates, with R=max⁡i∥xi∥R = \max_i \|x_i\|R=maxi​∥xi​∥.

Simple intuition:

  • The margin γ\gammaγ is how “thick” the gap is between the two classes. A bigger gap means the data is easier to separate.
  • RRR is the farthest distance any data point is from the origin—think of it as the “size” of your dataset.
  • The formula says: if your data points are spread out (large RRR) or the classes are close together (small γ\gammaγ), you’ll need more updates. But if there’s a nice big gap between classes, learning happens quickly.
  • In plain terms: well-separated data = fast learning. Messy, overlapping data = slow or impossible learning.

Two intuitive takeaways:

  • Larger margins = faster learning
  • Higher dimensionality doesn’t harm convergence (no curse of dimensionality here)

⸻

  1. What a Perceptron Cannot Do

Anything non-linearly separable:

  • XOR
  • Circular boundaries
  • Interleaved spirals

Mathematically: no single hyperplane can satisfy:

yi(w⋅xi+b)>0y_i(w \cdot x_i + b) > 0yi​(w⋅xi​+b)>0

for all samples.

In more detail:

Perceptron: One line cannot isolate diagonally opposite points.

A decision tree: Two axis-aligned splits create four boxes → perfectly solves XOR.

⸻

The Modern Solution: Multi-Layer Perceptrons

The fundamental limitation of a single perceptron is that it can only create one linear decision boundary. However, by stacking multiple perceptrons together—creating layers—we can learn non-linear decision boundaries.

The key insight:

  • A single layer = one hyperplane = linear separation
  • Multiple layers = composition of hyperplanes = non-linear separation

How it works:

  1. Hidden layers: Intermediate layers between input and output transform the data through multiple linear operations
  2. Activation functions: Non-linear functions (like ReLU, sigmoid, or tanh) applied after each layer’s linear transformation enable the network to model complex patterns
  3. Composition: Each layer builds on the previous one, allowing the network to learn increasingly abstract features

For XOR specifically:

  • Layer 1 creates two linear boundaries (two hyperplanes)
  • Layer 2 combines these boundaries to form the XOR pattern
  • The composition of linear functions, with non-linear activations, creates a non-linear decision boundary

Mathematical intuition: Instead of: y^=sign(w⋅x+b)\hat{y} = \text{sign}(w \cdot x + b)y^​=sign(w⋅x+b)

We have: y^=f2(W2⋅f1(W1⋅x+b1)+b2)\hat{y} = f_2(W_2 \cdot f_1(W_1 \cdot x + b_1) + b_2)y^​=f2​(W2​⋅f1​(W1​⋅x+b1​)+b2​)

Where f1f_1f1​ and f2f_2f2​ are activation functions, and W1,W2W_1, W_2W1​,W2​ are weight matrices. This composition allows the model to learn non-linear mappings.

Why this matters: Modern deep learning is built on this principle: stacking perceptron-like units (neurons) with non-linear activations enables models to approximate any continuous function (universal approximation theorem). The perceptron’s simplicity becomes the building block for neural networks that can solve complex, non-linearly separable problems.

BONUS MATH -> DOT PRODUCT

The dot product is a way of measuring alignment between two vectors.

Given two vectors u,v∈Rdu, v \in \mathbb{R}^du,v∈Rd, the dot product is:

u⋅v=∑i=1duiviu \cdot v = \sum_{i=1}^d u_i v_iu⋅v=∑i=1d​ui​vi​

Two key interpretations: 1. Geometric: u⋅v=∥u∥ ∥v∥cos⁡θu \cdot v = \|u\|\,\|v\|\cos\thetau⋅v=∥u∥∥v∥cosθ It’s large and positive when the vectors point in a similar direction, zero when they’re perpendicular, and negative when they point in opposite directions. 2. Algebraic: It’s a weighted sum—each component of uuu scaled by the corresponding component of vvv.

Why it matters for perceptrons: w⋅xw \cdot xw⋅x tells you how aligned an input xxx is with the model’s weight vector www. That alignment determines on which side of the hyperplane the point lands.
